Award.AwardTitle: Transnational Adoptees and Migrants: From Peru to Spain

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Jessaca B. Leinaweaver (Brown University) will undertake research on the relationship between international adoption and international migration, in situations where the populations involved in these movements share common origins and common destinations. Immigration typically has been studied by social scientists as a national or international phenomenon, while international adoption has been studied at the level of the individual or family. By bringing the two kinds of population movement into comparison with each other, Leinaweaver will be able to elucidate common and differentiating factors in the countries of origin and destination; how the two may interact, particularly with regard to integration into the receiving country; and how the identities and experiences of young immigrants are affected by being either adopted or part of labor-migrant families.

The research will be conducted in Spain and Peru, focusing on Peruvian children adopted to Spain and Peruvian youth who are part of families who immigrated to Spain for work. Data will be collected through a variety of ethnographic fieldwork methods including participant-observation, semi-structured focus group interviews, and semi-structured interviews with individuals and families. A graduate student employed by the project will also analyze print and electronic media from Spain and Peru to gather further evidence of how the diverse Peruvian presences in Spain are popularly mediated and understood. Findings from this research will contribute to social science theory of contemporary international population movements. The research also will be useful to government officials, non-governmental workers, and development agencies charged with developing and implementing migration and adoption policies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this research study was to determine how international adoption and international immigration are similar and how they differ, in terms of outcomes for immigrant integration into the host society. It does so by controlling for sending and receiving country (country of origin and country of destination) – both the labor migrants and the adopted children in this study come from Peru, and now reside in Spain. The purpose of seeking this information was to discover the relative significance of national origin versus other contributors to identity development across different patterns of transnational mobility.

Through ethnographic field research, developing databases of media and online forum contributions, collecting and analyzing legal documents, and situating the findings within broader demographic trends, researchers on this project found that despite policies and educational efforts aiming to minimize racism and the different treatment of adopted children (and other immigrants) and promote their integration, internationally adopted youth continue to experience everyday forms of racism that affect the way that they, and others like them, integrate into the host society. Internationally adopted youth often physically resemble immigrants, since they have come from the same countries that labor immigrants have. But unlike many labor immigrants, most international adoptees have been raised by native-born adoptive parents who teach them that they are an important part of native society.  Therefore, their experiences of racism are extremely jarring, but are also particularly good clues to the multiple and often invisible kinds of racism or anti-immigrant speech and actions that exist in a host society with a high rate of immigration. 

This project collected empirical information about the experiences of Hispanic populations in Spain, analyzing two transnational (ie. from one country to another) social and demographic processes with great importance in the US: labor migration and international adoption. Both Spain and the US have relatively high percentages of immigrants (14 percent and 12.5 percent respectively). Seeing what is working in Spain and what is failing can bring new ideas and data to the ongoing process of immigration reform. Developing policies based on those findings may allow legislators to minimize what can be a conflictive experience and to promote immigrant integration.  Furthermore, Spain and the U.S. are also similar in having high levels of international adoption, relative to the number of births in each country. Spain’s per capita rate of international adoptions is actually even higher than the U.S.’s, although the U.S. has the highest total annual number in the world. Because international adoption continues to be a key way that Americans who want to become parents seek to form stable families; and because this process is often controversial, involving tensions between “sending” and “receiving” societies, it is important to understand what the adopted children may experience as they grow up. This research found that international adoption is not only a family-formation strategy, but also a form of international migration, in the sense that children cross borders and come to be seen as immigrants, facing all the positive and the prejudicial values associated with that status. This finding is highly relevant to US taxpayers who are part of adoptive families or who value the healthy development of children and adolescents in US society.
